title: Pahari Painting - Multiple Choice Questions
subtitle: NIOS Class 12 Painting - Pahari Miniature Painting (Kangra, Basohli & Chamba Styles)

questions.question: What does the term 'Pahari painting' refer to?
options: Miniature painting tradition from hilly regions of India
questions.explanation: Pahari painting is a term used for miniature painting tradition that flourished in the hilly regions of India such as Himachal Pradesh, Jammu and Tehri-Garhwal.

questions.question: During which period did Pahari painting flourish?
questions.explanation: Pahari painting flourished in the hilly regions between circa 1675 to 1823 CE.

questions.question: Who patronized Pahari painting?
options: Local Rajas who were mainly Rajputs
questions.explanation: Pahari painting was patronized by the local Rajas of hilly regions, who were mainly Rajputs.

questions.question: What style characteristic defines Pahari painting?
questions.explanation: Pahari painting is a lyrical style of painting, known for its poetic and expressive qualities.

questions.question: Which religious epics were frequently painted in Pahari style?
questions.explanation: Fine paintings based on religious epics like Mahabharat and Ramayana, Puranas, Gita Govinda and Rasamanjari were frequently painted in Pahari style.

questions.question: Which Sanskrit and Hindi classics were popular in Pahari paintings?
questions.explanation: Sanskrit and Hindi classics such as Rasikapriya, Baramasa and Bihari Satsai were other popular texts that found representation in Pahari painting.

questions.question: What secular love stories were depicted in Pahari paintings?
questions.explanation: Secular themes included love stories of Hira-Ranjha, Sohani-Mahiwal and Sassi-Punno, among others.

questions.question: What type of color scheme is used in Pahari paintings?
questions.explanation: In Pahari paintings, generally bright colours were used in contrast.

questions.question: What is an important component of Pahari painting composition?
questions.explanation: Depiction of nature formed an important component of the composition of Pahari painting.

questions.question: Which of the following is a school of Pahari painting?
questions.explanation: Kangra, Basohli, Mankot, Guler, Jammu, Mandi, Chamba, Bilaspur, Kulu and Garhwal are schools of Pahari painting.

questions.question: Who was the famous patron of Kangra painting?
questions.explanation: Under the Royal Patronage of Raja Sansar Chand, Kangra painting reached a great height in beautiful portrayal of human form and nature.

questions.question: Who was the famous patron from Basohli?
questions.explanation: Among the famous patrons, Kirpal Pal from Basohli made a significant contribution to the development of Pahari painting.

questions.question: Who were famous Pahari painters?
options: Raja Ravi Varma and M.F. Husain
questions.explanation: Nainsukh, Manaku, Kushan Lal, Fattu and Ram Lal, Pundit Seu and Purkhu were some of the famous Pahari painters.

questions.question: What inspired Kangra artists besides royal patronage?
options: The culture of Punjab and the Great Sikh Movement started by Guru Nanak
questions.explanation: The culture of Punjab and the Great Sikh Movement started by Guru Nanak also inspired Kangra artists.

questions.question: Which texts were illustrated in Kangra style?
options: Gita Govinda of Jayadeva and Ramayana of Tulsidas
questions.explanation: The 'Gita Govinda' of Jayadeva and 'Ramayana' of Tulsidas have been illustrated in Kangra style.

questions.question: What did Sansar Chand commission from his childhood to old age?
questions.explanation: Sansar Chand commissioned many portraits of himself from his childhood to old age.

questions.question: Kangra art is described as a culmination of what?
options: Spiritual and literary revival of Hinduism
questions.explanation: Kangra art is a culmination of the spiritual and literary revival of Hinduism.

questions.question: What aspect do Kangra paintings disregard?
questions.explanation: Kangra paintings disregard perspective but focus on wonderful glowing colours and delicate line work.

questions.question: How are faces typically drawn in Kangra paintings?
questions.explanation: Almost all faces are drawn in profile in Kangra paintings.

questions.question: How can Kangra paintings be easily identified?
options: By delicacy of lines, brilliant colours and minuteness of decorative detail
questions.explanation: Kangra paintings can easily be identified by the delicacy of lines, brilliant colours and minuteness of decorative detail.

questions.question: What is a specialty of female figures in Kangra paintings?
options: Gazelle-like eyes, straight noses and beautifully chiselled faces
questions.explanation: Females with gazelle-like eyes, straight noses and beautifully chiselled faces are speciality of Kangra paintings.

questions.question: What is the thick paper used for miniature painting called?
questions.explanation: Thin layers of paper were joined layer by layer to make one thick paper called Wasli.

questions.question: What was Wasli paper coated with?
options: Glue of kikar plant mixed with white clay (Kharia Mitti) and sometimes egg white
questions.explanation: Wasli paper was coated with glue of kikar plant mixed with white clay (Kharia Mitti) and also sometimes with egg white.

questions.question: Why was coating applied to Wasli paper?
options: So that pores get filled and the paper becomes smooth
questions.explanation: A thin coat was applied to the Wasli paper so that the pores in the paper get filled, and the paper becomes smooth.

questions.question: From what source was red colour obtained in Kangra paintings?
questions.explanation: Red colour was obtained from Lahi (an insect) or beetroot in Kangra paintings.

questions.question: How was blue colour obtained in Kangra paintings?
questions.explanation: Blue colour was obtained from Jamun or neel in traditional Kangra painting technique.

questions.question: What sources provided yellow colour in Kangra paintings?
questions.explanation: Yellow colour came from turmeric, Ramraj (a stone) or Goguli (stone).

questions.question: From what was green colour made in Kangra paintings?
questions.explanation: Green colour was obtained from lapis Lazuli or boiling leaves.

questions.question: How was black colour obtained?
questions.explanation: Black colour was obtained from Kajal (lamp black) in Kangra painting technique.

questions.question: From what was golden colour obtained?
questions.explanation: Golden colour was obtained from the peel of anar (Pomegranate).

questions.question: What was the first step in creating a Kangra miniature painting?
options: Outline was either drawn or traced on Wasli paper
questions.explanation: The first step was that the outline was either drawn or traced on Wasli paper.

questions.question: What type of brushes were used in Kangra paintings?
options: Brushes made with squirrel or horse hair
questions.explanation: Opaque colour was applied with a brush made with squirrel or horse hair.

questions.question: What was special about the thinnest brushes used?
options: Made with one or two hair strands
questions.explanation: The process started with a very thin brush made of one or two hair strands.

questions.question: What shading method was used in Kangra paintings?
questions.explanation: Shading was done in stippling method in Kangra painting technique.

questions.question: What materials were used for depicting jewellery in Kangra paintings?
questions.explanation: Gold and silver thin foils were used for jewellery in Kangra miniature paintings.

questions.question: What was the final step in creating a Kangra painting?
options: Painting was polished with smooth surfaced stone
questions.explanation: Finally, the painting was polished with smooth surfaced stone.

questions.question: What is the title of the famous Kangra painting from 1820-30 CE?
questions.explanation: The famous painting is titled 'Under the Kadamba Tree' and dates from 1820-30 CE.

questions.question: What is the central theme of Kangra painting?
questions.explanation: The central theme of Kangra painting is love, and its sentiments are expressed in a style full of rhythm, grace and beauty.

questions.question: Who is shown romancing under the Kadamba tree?
questions.explanation: Krishna is shown romancing Radha under the Kadamba tree in deep woods near the bank of Yamuna.

questions.question: What birds are shown inside the foliage of the Kadamba tree?
questions.explanation: Inside the thick foliage of the Kadamba tree, peacock and other birds are shown.

questions.question: What rasa (sentiment) does 'Under the Kadamba Tree' express?
questions.explanation: This painting expresses the Sringara Rasa (romantic sentiment), where Krishna and Radha are shown embracing each other.

questions.question: What is the title of another famous Kangra painting from 1800 CE?
questions.explanation: The painting titled 'The Rains' is from the Kangra style and dates to 1800 CE.

questions.question: What is shown in 'The Rains' painting?
options: An aristocratic couple on a palace roof under rain-filled sky
questions.explanation: An aristocratic couple has been shown on a palace roof under a rain-filled sky in 'The Rains'.

questions.question: What does 'Baramasa' refer to?
options: The twelve months of the year
questions.explanation: The twelve months of the year 'Baramasa' have delighted Hindu poets and painters.

questions.question: Who was the great poet that described life during different seasons?
questions.explanation: Kesavadas, a great poet, described the life of people during these seasons, which were rendered into paintings by Kangra artists.

questions.question: What characteristic of Kangra painters is shown in 'The Rains'?
questions.explanation: Kangra painters were deeply in love with nature, as shown in paintings like 'The Rains.'

questions.question: What are the salient features of Kangra paintings?
options: Delicate lines, soft and subtle colours, minute details
questions.explanation: The salient features are delicate lines with which various forms and figures are rendered, soft and subtle colours, and minute details with decorative qualities.

questions.question: What characterizes Basohli paintings?
options: Simple works full of strength and primitive vitality
questions.explanation: Basohli paintings are simple works full of strength and primitive vitality.

questions.question: What dominates the pattern in Basohli paintings?
questions.explanation: The pattern in Basohli paintings is dominated by lines and colours.

questions.question: How did Basohli painters work?
options: With fearless passion imparting energy and power
questions.explanation: Basohli painters worked with fearless passion imparting energy and power to their works.

questions.question: What did Basohli artists achieve?
questions.explanation: Basohli artists attained maximum expression with minimum means.

questions.question: What are special features of 17th-century Basohli paintings?
questions.explanation: Lush landscapes are special features of 17th-century Basohli paintings, with 'Love Pavilion' frequently seen set in these landscapes.

questions.question: Who was the ruler that developed fondness for illustrated manuscripts in Basohli?
questions.explanation: Raja Kirpal was the ruler who developed a fondness for possessing illustrated manuscripts on varieties of subjects.

questions.question: What manuscripts were illustrated in Basohli with prominent Krishna presence?
questions.explanation: Rasamanjari, Bhagwatpurana, and Gita Govinda were illustrated and Krishna had a prominent presence in all these manuscripts.

questions.question: What text did Basohli rulers have special fondness for throughout 18th century?
questions.explanation: Throughout the 18th century, Basohli rulers had a special fondness for 'Rasamanjari' and produced finest illustrations.

questions.question: Who painted the romantic text Rasamanjari in 1694-95?
questions.explanation: The finest illustrations of Rasamanjari, the romantic text by Bhanudatta, were painted by artist Devidas (1694-95).

questions.question: What are characteristics of Basohli style?
options: Ethnic types, bold colour schemes, wooden architectural motifs, large staring eyes, robust figures
questions.explanation: Basohli style is characterized by ethnic types, bold colour schemes, wooden architectural motifs, large staring eyes, and robust figures.

questions.question: What is the title of the celebrated Basohli painting from 1660-70 CE?
options: Krishna Romancing Radha with a Lotus
questions.explanation: The celebrated painting 'Krishna Romancing Radha with a Lotus' is from Basohli, period 1660-70 CE.

questions.question: How is Basohli Krishna different from Kangra Krishna?
options: Urban and suave, resembling nobility and royalty
questions.explanation: Unlike Kangra Krishna, Basohli Krishna is urban and suave, resembling nobility and royalty more than the pastoral cowherd.

questions.question: How is Radha depicted in Basohli style compared to Kangra?
options: Royal and confident, different from shy Radha of Kangra
questions.explanation: Radha is seen sitting in a royal and confident manner in Basohli, very different from the shy Radha of Kangra school.

questions.question: What colour is Krishna's body painted in Basohli paintings?
questions.explanation: The blue-bodied Krishna is a characteristic feature of Basohli paintings.

questions.question: What is Krishna holding when approaching Radha in 'Krishna Romancing Radha with a Lotus'?
questions.explanation: Dressed in an orange dhoti, the blue-bodied Krishna with a golden scarf is approaching Radha with a lotus flower.

questions.question: What background color brightens the composition in 'Krishna Romancing Radha with a Lotus'?
questions.explanation: The brilliant yellow in the background brightens the entire composition.

questions.question: What is the title of another Basohli painting from 1660-70 CE?
questions.explanation: Another famous Basohli painting is 'Krishna with a Companion' from the period 1660-70 CE.

questions.question: What is Krishna doing in 'Krishna with a Companion'?
options: Expressing his loneliness as Radha is away
questions.explanation: Krishna is expressing his loneliness to his companion as Radha is away in this painting.

questions.question: How is Radha's absence indicated in 'Krishna with a Companion'?
questions.explanation: The absence of Radha is indicated by the empty bed in the painting.

questions.question: What marks on the companion's body indicate his Vaishnavite affiliation?
questions.explanation: His bare upper body has sandal marks indicating his Vaishnavite affiliation.

questions.question: How do Basohli paintings compare to Kangra in terms of boldness?
options: Bold and simple with very bright direct colours
questions.explanation: Basohli paintings are bold and simple compared to Kangra paintings, with very bright and direct colours compared to subtle tones of Kangra.

questions.question: What characterizes Basohli style in terms of facial features?
options: Large staring eyes and faces in profile
questions.explanation: Basohli style is characterised by large staring eyes, faces in profile and multiple perspective.

questions.question: Where did the Chamba school of painting flourish?
options: In a small hill town of Himachal Pradesh
questions.explanation: Chamba school of painting flourished in a small hill town of Himachal Pradesh.

questions.question: What inspired the Chamba school of art?
questions.explanation: Inspired by the Krishna cult and Vaishnavism, the Chamba school of art presented one of the finest collection of paintings.

questions.question: What were the main themes of Chamba paintings?
options: Dasavatara Series, Vishwarupa Series, Bhagvata Purana Series, and Ramayana
questions.explanation: The main themes were (1) Dasavatara Series (1725-50 CE) (2) The Vishwarupa Series (18th CE) (3) Bhagvata Purana Series (1757 CE) and (4) Ramayana (1750-75 CE).

questions.question: What paper did Chamba artists use?
questions.explanation: Papers used by the Chamba artists were Wasli, same as other miniature painting traditions.

questions.question: What materials were applied to Chamba paintings and then polished?
options: Gold, silver and other materials, later polished with smooth stone from both sides
questions.explanation: Gold, silver and other materials were applied to Chamba paintings, which were later polished with smooth stone from both sides.

questions.question: What painting tradition influenced Chamba in style and colour?
questions.explanation: The Chamba center was influenced by Mughal miniature painters both in style and colour, though it retained its local characteristics.

questions.question: What is the title of the famous Chamba painting?
questions.explanation: The famous Chamba painting is titled 'Vishvarupa I' from the Vishwarupa Series.

questions.question: What is unusual about the Vishvarupa I painting?
options: Heads, arms, and legs painted in different colors - red, green, grey, blue, yellow, pink
questions.explanation: This is an unusual colourful Vishvarupa since the heads, arms, and legs have been painted in different colours - red, green, grey, blue, yellow, and pink.

questions.question: How many arms does the deity have in Vishvarupa I?
questions.explanation: Twenty-four arms are painted in rounded formations of different hues holding various weapons, lotuses, a conch shell, a temple bell, possibly the Vedas and a snake.

questions.question: How many heads are there in total in Vishvarupa I?
questions.explanation: There are four layers of heads with four central heads and 23 profile heads on each layer, making them 52 in total.

questions.question: What covers the torso in Vishvarupa I?
options: Bark-like vegetation with figures of Brahma, Shiva, Sun and Moon
questions.explanation: The torso is covered in bark-like vegetation from which we see figures of Brahma, Shiva, Sun and Moon peeping out.

questions.question: Who are the two standing figures with folded hands in Vishvarupa I?
questions.explanation: There are two figures, one is of women the other one is a man, standing with folded hands. These figures are probably of King and Queen.

questions.question: What is the size of Vishvarupa I?
questions.explanation: The painting Vishvarupa I measures 30.2 cm × 23.8 cms.

questions.question: What are the characteristic features of Chamba paintings?
options: Indigenous style, inspired by Krishna cult, liberal use of bright flat colours, complicated symbolic representation
questions.explanation: Chamba paintings are characterized by indigenous style, inspiration from Krishna cult, liberal use of bright flat colours, and complicated symbolic representation.

questions.question: When was the Dasavatara Series of Chamba paintings created?
questions.explanation: The Dasavatara Series was created during 1725-50 CE as one of the main themes of Chamba paintings.

questions.question: When was the Bhagvata Purana Series created in Chamba style?
questions.explanation: The Bhagvata Purana Series was created in 1757 CE as one of the main themes of Chamba paintings.

questions.question: When was the Ramayana series created in Chamba style?
questions.explanation: The Ramayana series was created during 1750-75 CE in Chamba style.

questions.question: What cult symbolized spiritual experience as relation of lover and beloved?
questions.explanation: The Vaishnava cult symbolized spiritual experience in relation of lover and beloved, influencing Pahari painting themes.

questions.question: What period saw great writers contributing to Vaishnavism and art development?
questions.explanation: Many great writers, poets and philosophers were born during the 16th and 17th centuries who contributed to spreading Vaishnavism and development of art.

questions.question: What is the medium used for Pahari miniature paintings?
questions.explanation: The medium used for Pahari miniature paintings was opaque watercolour on specially prepared paper called Wasli.

questions.question: How did Jayadeva's Gita Govinda inspire Pahari artists?
options: Through divine love of Krishna and Radha as theme
questions.explanation: Jayadeva's Gita Govinda became a favorite for love songs based on the divine love of Krishna and Radha, providing major inspiration for Pahari artists.

questions.question: What is stippling in painting technique?
options: Creating shading through dots or small marks
questions.explanation: Stippling is a shading method done by creating texture or tonal gradation through dots or small marks, used in Kangra painting technique.

questions.question: What does 'Sringara Rasa' represent?
questions.explanation: Sringara Rasa is the romantic or erotic sentiment in Indian aesthetics, prominently expressed in paintings like 'Under the Kadamba Tree.'

questions.question: What does the painting under the Kadamba tree symbolize spiritually?
options: Human soul awakened by the realization of God
questions.explanation: The painting depicts awakening like the human soul awakened by the realization of God, and the coming together of two into one.

questions.question: What collection houses 'Under the Kadamba Tree'?
questions.explanation: The painting 'Under the Kadamba Tree' is in the Harsh D Dehejia collection.

questions.question: Where are the Basohli paintings 'Krishna Romancing Radha' and 'Krishna with Companion' housed?
questions.explanation: Both celebrated Basohli paintings are in the Victoria Albert Museum, London collection.

questions.question: What does 'Vishvarupa' literally mean?
questions.explanation: Vishvarupa means universal or cosmic form, representing the divine in all its manifestations, as depicted in Chamba paintings.

questions.question: What is the difference between Basohli and Kangra Krishna?
options: Basohli Krishna is urban/royal while Kangra Krishna is pastoral
questions.explanation: Basohli Krishna is urban and suave, resembling nobility and royalty, while Kangra Krishna is more pastoral and prankish cowherd-like.

questions.question: What was the driving force behind Kangra art according to the text?
questions.explanation: The cult of Bhakti was the driving force behind Kangra art, combined with Vaishnava revival and spiritual-literary movements.

questions.question: What makes Pahari painting schools distinct from each other?
options: Each developed unique characteristics while sharing common themes
questions.explanation: While schools like Kangra, Basohli, and Chamba share common themes from Vaishnavism, each developed unique stylistic characteristics, color palettes, and artistic approaches.

questions.question: What is the significance of using natural materials for colors in Pahari paintings?
options: They created luminous, lasting colors connected to traditional knowledge
questions.explanation: Natural materials like minerals, plants, and insects created luminous, lasting colors and represented traditional artistic knowledge passed through generations, connecting the art to its cultural and environmental context.
